channel.title: Machine Learning on
channel.description: Recent content in Machine Learning on

item.title: Building Diffusion Models (7/7): Text-to-Image Conditioning
item.description: Unconditional diffusion generates random images. Conditioning lets you control what’s generated.

item.title: Building Diffusion Models (6/7): Sampling and Generation
item.description: Model trained. Now generate images. Start with random noise, repeatedly denoise, arrive at a realistic image.

item.title: Building Diffusion Models (5/7): Training the Denoiser
item.description: Architecture ready. Now train it. Diffusion training is simple in principle but requires careful implementation for good results.

item.title: Building Diffusion Models (4/7): U-Net Architecture
item.description: The denoiser needs to see both big picture and fine details.

item.title: Building Diffusion Models (3/7): The Noise Process
item.description: Diffusion’s key insight: destroying structure is easy (add noise), creating structure is hard.

item.title: Building Diffusion Models (2/7): Neural Network Basics
item.description: Neural networks learn to denoise images. Before building a full diffusion model, understand the building blocks: conv layers, activations, residual connections.

item.title: Building Diffusion Models (1/7): Understanding Tensors
item.description: Before diving into diffusion models, master the foundation: tensors. Every image is a tensor.

item.title: Multimodal LLMs: When AI Sees and Reads
item.description: Text-only LLMs miss half the world. Images, diagrams, charts, photos. Multimodal models see and read - understanding both modalities together.

item.title: How to Fine-Tune LLMs for Your Use Case
item.description: Pretrained LLMs are generalists. Fine-tuning makes them specialists. Adapt to your domain, your style, your task.

item.title: RAG: Retrieval-Augmented Generation Explained
item.description: LLMs have a knowledge cutoff. They hallucinate. RAG fixes this: retrieve relevant documents first, then generate answer based on retrieved context.

item.title: Variational Autoencoders: Probabilistic Generation
item.description: Autoencoders compress data to a bottleneck, then reconstruct. VAEs make the bottleneck probabilistic - encode to a distribution, sample from it, decode.

item.title: The Exploration-Exploitation Dilemma in RL
item.description: The exploration-exploitation dilemma: do you try new things (might be better) or stick with what works (guaranteed decent)?

item.title: Q-Learning: Mastering Action Values
item.description: Learn the value of actions without knowing environment dynamics. Q-learning: simple, powerful, the foundation of DQN and modern deep RL.

item.title: Reinforcement Learning: Foundations and Key Concepts
item.description: Supervised learning needs labeled data. What if there’s no teacher? RL learns from interaction - take actions, observe outcomes, maximize reward.

item.title: BERT: Bidirectional Language Understanding
item.description: Before BERT: train models from scratch for each task. After BERT: pretrain once, fine-tune everywhere.

item.title: The Transformer Architecture: Model Behind Modern AI
item.description: The paper that changed everything: “Attention Is All You Need” (2017).

item.title: How Transformers Know Position: Positional Encoding
item.description: Self-attention is permutation equivariant. Shuffle the input tokens, output shuffles the same way.

item.title: Self-Attention: The Key to Transformers
item.description: Regular attention: query from one sequence, attend to another. Self-attention: query, key, value all come from same sequence.

item.title: Attention Mechanisms (Part 1): The Core Idea
item.description: LSTMs helped with long-range dependencies. Attention does something more powerful - direct connections from anywhere to anywhere.

item.title: LSTMs: Learning Long-Term Dependencies
item.description: RNNs have short memory. Information from early timesteps fades quickly. LSTMs fix this with gates that control information flow.

item.title: Layer Normalization for Stable Training
item.description: Deep networks have unstable activations. Values explode or vanish as they pass through layers.

item.title: Conv + ReLU: The CNN Building Block
item.description: Convolution followed by ReLU. This pattern repeats hundreds of times in modern image networks.

item.title: 2D Convolutions: How Neural Networks See Images
item.description: Images are grids of pixels. Fully connected layers would need billions of parameters.

item.title: Why Cross-Entropy Works for Classification
item.description: Why do we use cross-entropy for classification? What does it actually measure?

item.title: FastText: When Words Aren't in Your Vocabulary
item.description: Word2Vec problem: what about misspellings? What about “unhappiness” when you only trained on “happy”?

item.title: GloVe: Global Vectors for Word Representation
item.description: Word2Vec uses local context windows. GloVe takes a different approach - use global word co-occurrence statistics.

item.title: Word2Vec: The Breakthrough in Word Embeddings
item.description: Before Word2Vec, representing words for ML was rough. One-hot encoding, TF-IDF… none of them captured meaning.

item.title: Embeddings: Turning Everything Into Vectors
item.description: Embeddings are everywhere now. Words, sentences, images, users, products… anything can be an embedding.

item.title: How Text Becomes Numbers: Tokenization Explained
item.description: ML models don’t read text. They need numbers. Tokenization bridges that gap.

item.title: Bag of Words: Still the Simplest Text Representation
item.description: Before embeddings there was Bag of Words. Still useful, still relevant for some tasks.

item.title: From Numbers to Probabilities: The Softmax Function
item.description: Neural network outputs raw numbers (logits). For classification, you want probabilities.

item.title: Leaky ReLU and the Dead Neuron Problem
item.description: ReLU is great but has a problem. Neurons can die. Leaky ReLU fixes this with one small change.

item.title: ReLU: The Simple Function That Powers Deep Learning
item.description: Sigmoid was the standard. Then ReLU came along and made deep learning actually work.

item.title: How Neural Networks Learn: Gradient Descent
item.description: Neural networks learn by adjusting weights to reduce error. Gradient descent tells you which direction to adjust.

item.title: Linear Regression: The Foundation of Machine Learning
item.description: Before deep learning there was linear regression. Still the most useful model for many problems.
